message.content:
cs.IT, cs.GT, cs.CR, cs.MM, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with the problem of source distinguishability under distortion limited attack, which involves information theory, game theory, and optimal transport theory. Therefore, cs.IT (Information Theory) is the most likely sub-category. The paper also introduces the concept of security margin, which is related to the notion of robustness in game theory, making cs.GT (Game Theory) a likely sub-category as well. The paper also discusses the impact of the distortion constraint on the distinguishability of the sources, which is related to the field of cryptography, making cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) a possible sub-category. The paper also mentions the mean square error as a measure of distortion, which is related to signal processing, making cs.MM (Multimedia) a possible sub-category. Finally, the paper discusses the error probabilities associated with the distinguishability problem, which is related to machine learning, making cs.LG (Machine Learning) a possible sub-category.
